Just a feeling that it might be Hizen, nothing specific, probably because of
the dragon.
Alan

----- Original Message -----
From: "Jim Gilbert" <jggilbert@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Tuesday, July 22, 2003 7:14 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Saotome tsuba


: The combination of the sukashi and the dragon isn't adding up to any group
I can think of even if it is carved rather than etched.  Not to say it's the
same type, but it reminds me a bit of the early type of tsuba with a dragon
carved down into a plain plate like the 3rd (last) guard here:
: http://home.earthlink.net/~jggilbert/kamakura.htm
:
: Some sources call that kind of guard the beginning of the Kamakura-bori
style, others see it as an elaboration of the Tosho or Katchushi style.
Both may be correct, in that a one-off experiment could grow into a
"school."  Or both may be wrong and the pieces were made by someone or a
group that had no actual connection with the makers of what look to us as
likely pre or post styles.
:
: Alan mentioned Hizen -- was that because of the style of the dragon?
:
: Jim
:
:
:   Jim -
:
:   Thanks. The dragon, etc could just be very, very low
:   relief carving. I really can't tell. If it's not Saotome,
:   what other schools might it be?
:
:   Rich
:
:
